| website = {{URL|russell-howard.co.uk}} }} '''Russell Joseph Howard''' (born 23 March 1980){{cite web|title=Russell Howard|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/r/537|work=Chortle|accessdate=28 December 2011}} is an English comedian, television presenter, radio presenter and actor, best known for his TV shows ''[[Russell Howard's Good News]]'' and ''[[The Russell Howard Hour]]'' and his appearances on the topical panel TV show ''[[Mock the Week]]''. He won "Best [[Master of Ceremonies#Comedy clubs|Compère]]" at the 2006 Chortle Awards and was nominated for an [[if.comedy award]] for his [[2006 Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] show. Howard cited comedians [[Lee Evans (comedian)|Lee Evans]], [[Richard Pryor]] and [[Frank Skinner]] as influences.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xIQDQ2r_wxo|title=Favourite Comedians – Russell Howard's Good News – BBC Three|date=18 November 2009|publisher=[[BBC]]}} ==Early life== Russell was born to Dave and Ninette Howard. He has two younger siblings, twins [[Kerry Howard|Kerry]] and Daniel (born 1982).{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/article5516562.ece | title=Relative Values: Russell Howard and his mother, Ninette |work=The Times |location=UK |date=18 January 2009 | accessdate=8 December 2009|subscription=yes}} Daniel has epilepsy, to which Howard sometimes refers during his act. Howard attended [[Perins School]] in [[New Alresford]] and [[Alton College]], both in [[Hampshire]]. He later studied economics at the [[University of the West of England]] in Bristol."[http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/bristol-news/11-bristol-celebrities-go-school-17024 Where did these 11 Bristol celebrities go to school?]",''Bristol Post'', 2 April 2017 (Accessed 4th April 2017){{cite news|title=Q & A: Comedian Russell Howard|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-2129376/Q-amp-A-Comedian-Russell-Howard.html|date=14 April 2012|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|last=Wilson|first=Benji}} ==Career== ===TV and radio work=== In 2004 he was commissioned by [[BBC Radio 1]] to write, sing and perform on the comedy series ''The Milk Run''. Howard has also appeared on the shows ''[[Banter (radio show)|Banter]]'' (hosted by [[Andrew Collins (broadcaster)|Andrew Collins]]) and ''[[Political Animal (radio)|Political Animal]]'' for [[BBC Radio 4]].{{cite magazine |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090105010705/http://www.national-student.co.uk/pages/magazine/comedy/russell_howard.html |archive-date=5 January 2009 |url=http://www.national-student.co.uk/pages/magazine/comedy/russell_howard.html |title=Russell Howard Interview '06 |work=The National Student Magazine |date=2006}} Until 2010, Howard was a regular panellist on ''Mock the Week''. He has also appeared on ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats]]'', ''[[Would I Lie To You? (TV series)|Would I Lie To You?]]'', ''[[Live at the Apollo (TV series)|Live at the Apollo]]'', ''[[The Secret Policeman's Ball 2008]]'', ''[[Law of the Playground]]'' and ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'' ([[List of Never Mind the Buzzcocks episodes|Series 18, Episode 2 and Series 20, Episode 4]]).{{cite web|title=Never Mind the Buzzcocks (a Guests & Air Dates Guide)|url=http://epguides.com/NeverMindtheBuzzcocks/|website=epguides.com|accessdate=30 January 2016|date=2 November 2015}} He was one of several comedians picked as the best comedy talent from the [[2005 Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] that recorded 10–15-minute spots for the 'Edinburgh and Beyond' show which was aired on [[Paramount Comedy 1]] in the autumn of 2006. The show was filmed at The [[Bloomsbury Theatre]]. From 2009, he took over as compère of this show from [[Al Murray]].{{cite web |url=http://www.comedycentral.co.uk/shows/edinburgh-and-beyond |title=Edinburgh And Beyond |work=Comedy Central |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805164613/http://www.comedycentral.co.uk/shows/edinburgh-and-beyond |archive-date=5 August 2009 |quote=For this latest series, starting Saturday July 25th 2009 Al Murray the Pub Landlord has sadly stepped down as your host and compere. But the good news is that he has been replaced by ''Mock The Week'' star Russell Howard, with his own brand of award-winning comedy.}} From November 2006 to July 2008, Russell co-hosted ''[[The Russell Howard Show]]'' on [[BBC 6 Music]] with fellow comedian [[Jon Richardson (entertainer)|Jon Richardson]] in a Sunday morning slot previously hosted by [[Russell Brand]].{{cite web|title=The Russell Howard Show|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/6music/shows/russell_howard/|website=BBC 6 Music|accessdate=30 January 2016}}[http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2006/11_november/02/howard.shtml "Russell Howard presents new show for 6 Music"] – BBC Press Release, 2 November 2006 The show continued to air, without Howard, until March 2010. He has since explained that his main reason for leaving the show was that he finds radio "really restrictive" and "I gorge off the audience as a performer, but you can't gauge a reaction on the radio."{{cite news|url=http://www.surreymirror.co.uk/Star-interview-Comedian-Russell-Howard-sold-Dorking-Crawley/story-12667330-detail/story.html|title=Star interview: Comedian Russell Howard sold out at Dorking and Crawley|work=Surrey Mirror|date=5 November 2008|access-date=30 January 2016}} Russell was commissioned to make a comedy show called ''[[Russell Howard's Good News]]'', aimed at under-25s, for [[BBC Three]]. The first episode aired on 22 October 2009 and the show ran for seven episodes as well as a "best of" show and a Christmas Special. It went on to become BBC Three's highest ever rating entertainment series.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportrelief.com/whats-on/challenges/cycle/meet-the-team/russell-howard|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100214023516/http://www.sportrelief.com/whats-on/challenges/cycle/meet-the-team/russell-howard|archivedate=14 February 2010|title=Russell Howard|publisher=Sport Relief|accessdate=17 October 2015}}{{cite web|title=Good News For Russell|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2009/08/29/9516|work=Chortle|date=29 August 2009|access-date=30 January 2016}} In the show, he gave his take on the week's major news stories, as well as giving attention to some of the more light-hearted stories of the week. Two more series of the show were commissioned, with the second series starting on 25 March 2010.{{cite web | url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2010/02/16/10525/ | title=Russell Howard's very good news |work=Chortle |date=16 February 2010 | accessdate=17 February 2010}} A seventh series began on 27 September 2012 on BBC Three. Series 8 began on 25 April 2013 on BBC Three, and series 9 started broadcast in its new home on [[BBC Two]] in October 2014. ''[[Russell Howard's Good News]]'' was voted the Best Ever BBC Three show on 9 February 2013{{cite web|first=Frances |last=Taylor |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/tv/news/a457613/russell-howards-good-news-voted-bbc-threes-best-ever-show/ |title='Russell Howard's Good News' voted BBC Three's best ever show |publisher=Digital Spy |date=9 February 2013 |accessdate=11 June 2016}} as part of the channel's 10th birthday celebrations.{{cite web|first=Alex |last=Fletcher |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a454935/ |title=Little Britain, Gavin & Stacey: What is BBC Three's best ever show? |publisher=Digital Spy |date=30 January 2013 |accessdate=31 May 2013}} Howard made his United States television debut on the 3 August 2011 episode of ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]''. Howard guest-hosted the second episode of the 27th series of ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'' on 30 September 2013. In November 2013 Howard made a surprise appearance in the North East market town [[Barnard Castle]] to preview his latest tour show, Wonderbox.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/NEWS/10705789.Comedian_Russell_Howard_confirms_intimate_Barnard_Castle_gig/|title=Comedian Russell Howard confirms intimate Barnard Castle gig|website=The Northern Echo|access-date=2017-01-17}} From 2015 to 2016, Howard presented a show called ''[[Chris Ramsey's Stand Up Central|Russell Howard's Stand Up Central]]'' which broadcasts on [[Comedy Central (UK and Ireland)|Comedy Central]]. However, in 2017 due to tour commitments, Howard was unable to present the show's third series and was replaced by [[Chris Ramsey (comedian)|Chris Ramsey]].https://www.comedy.co.uk/tv/news/2573/chris_ramsey_stand_up_central/ In 2015 he appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon]]'' where he performed some stand-up. In December 2015, Howard made his acting debut in BBC Two's hour-long comedy-drama ''[[A Gert Lush Christmas]]'', which he also co-wrote. In the film, Howard played Dan Colman, who takes his girlfriend to meet his family in Bristol for Christmas. The film also co-starred Howard's sister Kerry, who played Dan's sister Julie. On 10 March 2016, Howard appeared on the BBC 1 panel show ''Room 101''. In March 2016 Howard attacked Conservative MP [[Philip Davies]] on his BBC show calling him an "arsehole", "windbag", "wanker" and a "toad-faced hypocrite", accusing the MP of filibustering (talking out a bill). Davies complained on the grounds of "inaccuracy" and "misrepresentation" and the BBC was forced to publish in the Clarifications and Corrections section of the BBC website stating "Davies did not personally use up all the time available for the debate and that almost three hours remained after he sat down". Howard was also found to have misrepresented Davies' views on the disabled and the BBC noted "that the programme did not fully represent his comments, which were, that it would be in the best interests of disabled people, and others, to be allowed to offer to work for less than the minimum wage, if the alternative were no employment at all". The broadcaster also agreed not to air the episode again due to their misrepresentation of Davies' position.http://uk.businessinsider.com/tory-philip-davies-furious-bbc-russell-howard-toad-faced-hypocrite-2016-9. The [[BBC Trust]] later rejected a further escalation of the complaint by Davies{{cite news|last=Sweney|first=Mark|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2016/sep/29/tory-mp-complaint-russell-howard-bbc-trust-philip-davies|title=Tory MP's complaint about Russell Howard jibes rejected by BBC Trust|work=The Guardian|date=29 September 2016|accessdate=29 September 2016}} Starting in October 2016, Howard presented a travel documentary series for Comedy Central called ''[[Russell Howard & Mum: USA Road Trip]]'' which involved him and his mother Ninette travelling through America.{{cite web |url=https://www.comedy.co.uk/videos/11803/russell_howard_mum_us_road_trip/ |title=Russell Howard & Mum: US Road Trip |first=|last=|publisher=British Comedy Guide}} On 29 November 2016, it was announced that Howard would write and star in a 14-part weekly comedy series entitled ''The Russell Howard Hour'' on [[Sky 1]] in 2017, as part of a two-year deal with [[Sky plc|Sky]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2017/01/27/26732/russell_howard_set_to_host_his_own_chat_show|title=Russell Howard set to host his own chat show : News 2017 : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide|first=Powder Blue Internet Business|last=Solutions|website=www.chortle.co.uk|accessdate=3 May 2017}} The series began on 21 September 2017. ===Live comedy=== A show from his 2007 ''Adventures'' tour was released on DVD on 17 November 2008,{{cite web | url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1433549/ | title=Russell Howard Live (2008) |work=Internet Movie Database | accessdate=8 December 2009}} under the title "Russell Howard Live". The show on the DVD was recorded at The [[Bloomsbury Theatre]].{{cite DVD notes |title=Russell Howard Live DVD |titlelink= |origyear=2007 |others=Peter Orton |type=Back Cover |publisher=Avalon Television Ltd}} Howard started touring for his show ''Dingledodies'' in September 2008 and played various dates through to December. Due to overwhelming demand he further extended the tour twice into 2009. It sold in excess of 125,000 tickets,{{cite DVD notes |title=Russell Howard Live Dingledodies DVD |titlelink= |origyear=2009 |others=Peter Orton |type=Back Cover |publisher=Avalon Television Ltd}} including three sell-out shows at the [[Hammersmith Apollo]] as well as several large arenas such as [[Wembley Arena]] and Manchester's [[MEN Arena]]. The DVD of this tour was released on 9 November 2009{{cite web |first=Rich |last=Goodman | url=http://www.myreviewer.com/DVD/122796/Russell-Howard--Dingledodies/About | title=Russell Howard: Dingledodies |work=MyReviewer.com |date=2 November 2009 | accessdate=8 December 2009}} and features a recording of the show from the [[Brighton Dome]]. Howard was named "Best Theatre Show" at the 2009 Chortle Comedy Awards.{{cite web | url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2009/02/24/8361/ |title=Rhod and Tim triumph at Chortles |work=Chortle |date=24 February 2009 | accessdate=17 February 2010}} Howard appeared in UK dates in December 2009 for his "Big Rooms and Belly Laughs" tour.{{cite web|url=http://iknowwhereitsat.com/tag/russell-howard/ |title=Russell Howard event listings |publisher= IKnowWhereItsAt.com|accessdate=17 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091215073336/http://iknowwhereitsat.com/tag/russell-howard/|archivedate=15 December 2009}} ''Right Here Right Now'', his 2011 arena tour, sold out. ''[[The Independent]]'' reported that Howard earned £4 million in 2009 alone,{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/features/funny-money-britains-jokers-are-cashing-in-1986873.html|title=Funny Money: Britain's Jokers are cashing in|location=London|work=The Independent|date=30 May 2010}} which he denies.{{cite web|last=Lewis |first=Helen|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/blogs/helen-lewis-hasteley/2011/04/russell-howard-funny-stuff-gay|title=I got invited to David Walliams's wedding . . . but I'd have just been on my own at the buffet|publisher=New Statesman|date=25 April 2011 |accessdate=17 December 2011}} On 23 April 2013 Howard confirmed that he would be performing a stand-up tour called ''Wonderbox'' starting in February 2014 with dates in Britain, Ireland, the United States, Australia and New Zealand.{{cite news|last1=Everett|first1=Lucinda|title=Russell Howard announces 2014 world stand-up tour, Wonderbox|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/comedy/10010517/Russell-Howard-announces-2014-world-stand-up-tour-Wonderbox.html|accessdate=1 February 2016|work=The Telegraph|date=23 April 2013}} The tour was released on DVD in November 2014. This was further extended to include more UK dates in December 2014. In November 2015, Howard announced that he would be doing a fifth stand-up tour in February to July 2017 called ''Round The World'' where he will tour the United Kingdom, Ireland, Europe, Australia, New Zealand and America. In advance of the tour, Howard plans to memorise the capital city of every country in the world alphabetically, in order to recite the full list at the start of each performance.{{cite web|last1=Lewis|first1=Roz|title=Russell Howard: 'Ryanair would charge you for sneezing if they could'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/celebritytravel/12067420/Russell-Howard-Ryanair-would-charge-youfor-sneezing-if-they-could.html|website=Telegraph|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=23 January 2016}} ==Personal life== Howard lives with his girlfriend Cerys, a doctor, in [[Camden, London]], and their dog, a [[Jack Russell terrier]] named Archie.{{cite news|last1=Sturgis|first1=India|title=Russell Howard: 'I have crippling low self-esteem'|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tv/2016/05/23/russell-howard-i-have-crippling-low-self-esteem/|accessdate=1 November 2016|work=Telegraph|date=23 May 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/comedy/10010856/Russell-Howard-interview-Twitter-isnt-useful-to-my-soul.html|last=Jones|first=Ross|title=Russell Howard interview: 'Twitter isn't useful to my soul'|work=The Telegraph|date=23 April 2013}} Howard appeared at [[Friends of the Earth]]'s LIVEstock comedy and music event at the [[Hammersmith Apollo]] in support of the [[Green Party of England and Wales|green]] campaign group's Food Chain Campaign for planet-friendly farming, on 12 November 2009. Since he was ten, Howard has supported [[Liverpool Football Club]].{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/im-glory-hunter-ive-cursed-12822314|title=Russell Howard on why he supports Liverpool|first=Paul|last=Gorst|date=30 March 2017|publisher=|accessdate=3 May 2017}} He has said that he is "deadly serious" about football.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/entertainment/celebrity/comedian-russell-howard-reading-newspapers-1073517|title=Comedian Russell Howard on reading newspapers and watching TV for a living |publisher=Daily Record|date=23 October 2010|first=Paul|last=English|accessdate=5 May 2012}} "I still go down the pub and play football with my mates", he commented in 2010. He played for [[Conference South]] team [[Basingstoke Town F.C.]] before becoming a comedian. In April 2010, Howard ran the [[2010 London Marathon|London Marathon]] for the first time with both his brother and sister, to raise money for [[Epilepsy Society]]. He completed the 26-mile course in 4 hours and 15 minutes, beating his target time of 5 hours. Sponsorship has raised over £7,000 to date.{{cite web|url=http://uk.virginmoneygiving.com/fundraiser-web/fundraiser/showFundraiserProfilePage.action?userUrl=russellhowardsrunning&isTeam=true |publisher=Virgin Money Giving | Fundraising |title=The Howards are raising money for Epilepsy |date=25 April 2010 |accessdate=17 December 2011}} For [[Sport Relief]] 2010 he took part in the [[BT Group|BT]] Sport Relief Million Pound Bike Ride with [[David Walliams]], [[Jimmy Carr]], [[Fearne Cotton]], [[Miranda Hart]], [[Patrick Kielty]] and [[Davina McCall]]. They cycled from John O'Groats in Scotland to Land's End in 4 days trying to raise £1 million. In November 2011 whilst filming a Mystery Guest segment for Good News, Howard broke his right hand when attempting to do press ups on a stunt chair.{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2011/11/16/14330/russell_howard_breaks_his_fingers|title=Russell Howard breaks his fingers : News 2011 : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide|first=Powder Blue Internet Business|last=Solutions|website=www.chortle.co.uk|accessdate=3 May 2017}} Russell was voted [[Heat Magazine]]'s "Weird Crush of the Year 2013",{{cite web|url=http://www.heatworld.com/2014/09/your-weird-crush-2013-winners#image-30|title=Your Weird Crush 2013 winners!|work=heatworld|last=Lewis|first=Anna|date=11 September 2014}} with his friend and former flatmate [[Jon Richardson (comedian)|Jon Richardson]] coming second. Howard mentioned on the DVD recording of his 2014 tour ''Wonderbox'' that he is an [[Atheism|atheist]].{{citation needed|date=February 2018}} On 1 March 2015, Howard took part in The Bath Half Marathon and completed it in 1 hour and 44 minutes in aid of Time Is Precious.
